author: ralexstokes
content: i am wondering how your `frontier` spec works wrt `parent_hash` validation

author: ralexstokes
content: what happens if i feed you a chain of blocks where each `parent_hash` is a random 32 bytes?

author: ralexstokes
content: as far as i can tell, the `state_transition` would work just fine, but then why does this field exist in the block header?

author: djrtwo
content: becuase clients maintain a block tree and apply child blocks to parent blocks in that tree

author: djrtwo
content: in CL, we store the parent_header in state and do an explicit check

author: djrtwo
content: but in EL, even if you are using the blockchain data structure to define where to apply a child block and what pre-state to use, you are implicitly checking chainedness

author: ralexstokes
content: yeah i looked a bit further and it seems that to the extent the spec is written so far, it just gets canonical blocks from another (RPC) source that has already run the fork choice

author: ralexstokes
content: the execution fork choice may be out-of-scope for this project, but if not it would be good to see the validation *somewhere*, even if implicit

author: djrtwo
content: yeah, interesting. if fork-choice ensures you have a blockchain on your hands (which it would have to to maintain a tree rather than a single chain), then you are good! but as a consumer of a pre-validated chain, I agree that it might be nice to see the validation explicitly
